copy.value:
The Volkswagen Amarok is a tough, award-winning ute, but as a newcomer with posh European styling, the Amarok was a long way from winning the trust of Australian tradesmen who rely heavily on their vehicles.

But the introduction of a new, extremely powerful V6 variant made the Amarok the most powerful ute in its class. This gave us the opportunity to challenge perceptions.

subline.value:
1. As the only V6 ute we need to announce our news and claim category leadership. Pick-up considerers needed to know that the Volkswagen Amarok is changing the ute market in Australia.
2. We also needed to get people excited, the power of a V6 is nothing short of extraordinary and we needed the communications to deliver on that and make them feel the thrill of the V6.

copy.value: We challenged preconceptions. If Aussie drivers were judging our pick-up by its cover, we needed to change the cover. We enlisted the help of Mad Max concept designer, Peter Pound, and built a completely new shell for the Amarok V6. It oozed performance and now looked just as mean as the V6 engine that powered it.

We then leaked spy shots to popular automotive sites. Editorial media channels spread the word and soon news of a mystery prototype being tested in the Australian bush appeared on blogs, forums and spy sites across the globe. Debate ignited as car fans guessed which company was behind the tough new vehicle.

Then, in partnership with Australia’s most popular Spy Shot website, we were able to retarget everyone who engaged with our campaign, revealing that the powerful mystery prototype was in fact an Amarok V6 in disguise.

To prove our capabilities we invited four unsuspecting performance enthusiasts to put the prototype to the test. With no preconceptions holding them back, the drivers were amazed by its power but were even more surprised when we revealed that this mean off-roader was actually the Amarok V6 in disguise.

Provide evidence of how successfully your objectives were achieved; what was the response rate and how was it measured? (3000 characters max).

Not only did we announce the launch of the new Amarok V6, generating a significant amount of intrigue and excitement but we also sold some utes. The Amarok V6 model made up 38% of the Amarok sales in the first month and has broken Amarok sales records every month since launch. 

In Australia, the word “ute” refers to a pick-up truck, mostly used by tradesmen. 
The Amarok is the newest model in this category and out audience is skeptical about its credentials.

Our strategy was to spread the news of our ‘mystery prototype’ through platforms where enthusiasts were already debating the origin of secret camouflaged prototypes. As we leaked spy footage and images, the enthusiasts leapt at the chance to give their opinion as to what this ‘thing’ was.  
On these platforms, they engaged and shared our campaign organically. From Manchester to Moscow, the world was talking about a prototype that wasn’t actually a prototype. 

Then, by retargeting our audience on various other channels, including YouTube and Facebook, we revealed that the powerful mystery prototype was actually an Amarok V6 in disguise.
DDB Sydney is looking for an Account Manager to join the team.

We are looking for someone who is passionate about getting the job done. You are, in fact, the ultimate project manager, firing on all cylinders all the time. You assist in the execution of all marketing activities and you are able to anticipate the entire process, from who is involved, to what needs to get done, and how it all fits together.<br class="all"><br class="all">

As an Account Managers you contribute to your client’s business through your strong understanding of the creative product and your role in its creation. You have a thirst for learning and can quickly pick up an in-depth understanding of the client, the client’s business and their consumer. You act and think creatively and strategically, contributing to the team, but also owning your projects and integrating around ideas.<br class="all"><br class="all"><br class="all">

DDB is looking for an established Account Director to join the team working on an exciting and fast paced account.

We are looking for an Account Director with exceptional client service experience across everything from TV to Digital/Content and Print. You are also a strong people manager able to coach and inspire your team.<br class="all"><br class="all">

Account Directors at DDB are solution-oriented, always thinking about their business, anticipating issues, and implementing their vision to produce superior results. They lead, facilitate and look for opportunities to expand into other disciplines.<br class="all"><br class="all"><br class="all">

Can we sell a Golf to town
that doesn’t need its city technology?

headline.value: So what was the brief then?

subline.value:
The job was to raise the consideration of the new model Golf,
boost understanding of its advanced tech features and deliver
more test-drives to Volkswagen dealers.

headline.value: An idea that was destined to fail…

subline.value:
We developed an online series about a Volkswagen dealer given an
impossible task. The premise was to sell the ultimate city car in
an outback town filled with folks with no want or need for it.

Our rep Tom, made a grand total of zero sales in the town but on Facebook
where the series was shown, viewers loved every awkward minute.

We turned Facebook into our broadcast channel, so we could
directly target potential buyers with the 6-month series.

meta-description.value: The landing page for DDB Group Australia.
About our principles at DDB Sydney.

headline.value:
How do brands and businesses actually grow?

We have long assumed that growth was anchored on a consumer who behaved logically and rationally to advance their lifestyle.

New evidence from the behavioral sciences refutes this. Far from being reasonable and rational, humans are emotional and often behave in a fashion that defies logic. Leading the debate is Nobel Prize winning Psychologist Daniel Kahneman who writes:

“We are feeling beings who can think, not thinking beings who can feel.”

text.value:
Thinking Fast, and Slow.
<br class="all">- Daniel Kahneman

headline.value:
A Challenge to Conventional Business Thinking

These revelations demand that we reappraise our long held beliefs and force us to challenge conventional business thinking. There are three main culprits that stand in the way of growth.

The belief that we need to win our category.
Our determination to win the mind of the consumer.
The pressure to win today.

This is legacy thinking grounded in the fallacious, rational mind models of positioning, persuasion, and the unique selling proposition.

We propose new rules of growth that are sympathetic to the latest evidence of the primacy of the emotional mind:

Fame dwarfs category.
Feeling conquers thinking.
Long term Fluency beats short term wins.

Unreasonable Growth in Practice

This has been validated in findings from the IPA in the UK and the Ehrenberg Bass Institute for Marketing Science.

We have turned these new rules into a simple, measurable and actionable approach for business growth and are having success with clients as diverse as Volkswagen, Expedia and MARS. Our tools and workshop practices help clients optimise their Fame, Feeling and Fluency and our partnership with the worlds leading System 1 research agency Brainjuicer means we are able to measure and benchmark a company’s performance against the three F’s.

copy.value: For those that buy the car, not the ad.

As a relative newcomer to the Australian automotive landscape the ŠKODA Octavia lacked awareness, it did however deliver on quality, design and engineering.
How could we get car buyers to open their eyes to the ŠKODA Octavia?

We set about calling out all the traditional car advertising clichés, challenging buyers to look behind the curtain. What they discovered was a brand determined to sell them a quality car vs. a clichéd image.
Sales for the Octavia have continued to strengthen since the campaign launched but more importantly awareness and saliency of the brand has a had a noticeable uplift.
*need a short punchy line to click through from homepage*
To establish the new identity ‘Proud supporters of you’ we leveraged the brand’s key sponsorship program – the Westpac Lifesaver Rescue Helicopter.
Encourage the next generation to open their first bank account with Westpac.
Stats say you’re more likely to get divorced than change bank accounts, so it’s vital to start a relationship with customers from an early age.
On January 1, 2017, we created a new kind of bank account, only exclusively available to unborn babies.
The Bump Account is a savings account open to all babies born in 2017.

But rather than being a short-term grab for new customers, the idea was to set the next generation of kids up for the future – so every account came with a $200 deposit, which can’t be accessed until the child’s 16th birthday.

Family and friends were encouraged to set up regular contributions on birthdays and at Christmas, as we showed how much small deposits could add up to over time, allowing them to save for university, a house deposit or a world trip.

The results were phenomenal, in just the first week alone:
- In one week the campaign generated 1.5million in PR.
- 16,220 accounts had been registered.
- 58% of those being non-Westpac customers.

Live response social, powered
by a smart application of technology.

We needed to get more people inside the
Sydney Opera House during summer.

subline.value:
8.2 million people visit the site of the
Sydney Opera House every year.

copy.value:
Most take photo if the outside and move on, making it the most
Instagrammed icon in Australia. People were a stick away.
We selected photos using computer vision, inviting
them inside with Instagram.

subline.value:
Turn photos of the Sydney Opera House on Instagram into
incredible experiences inside by inviting users to #comeonin.

quote.value: Have a look inside, because this is where it all happens

copy.value: 126 unsuspecting Instagrammers invited to #comeonin.

subline.value:
Custom software uses computer vision to identify photos of the
famous sails along with geo-location to find ones posted in close proximity.
An on-site response team picks an Instagram user for an experience and quickly
film and posts a video response inviting them inside.

In 4 weeks, over 5 million people saw a new side to the
Sydney Opera House: the inside.

To establish the new identity ‘Proud supporters of you’ we leveraged the brand’s key sponsorship program – the Westpac Lifesaver Rescue Helicopter.

Through an epic, single-take, the film tells the story of a man and his son floating helplessly in the ocean beside their upturned yacht. They drift, totally at the mercy of the elements, only to be plucked from danger by the arrival of the chopper.
Meanwhile, a voiceover expresses the key message that Westpac is there for all Australians, regardless of who they bank with.
In just two weeks 80% of people could spontaneously attribute the campaign to Westpac and best of all, it resonated most with our toughest audience, millennials.
When is a car more than a car?

subline.value: We needed to remind people that Volkswagen is entrenched in Aussie culture.

copy.value: We asked when is a car more than a car? →

As the brand name suggests, this is the people’s car
– a legacy that transcends sheet metal and machinery.
This was the thinking that gave rise to the campaign line
“When is a car more than a car? When it’s a Volkswagen.”

But for the message to really hit home, it couldn’t come from us.
We reached out to real Volkswagen owners and asked them to
share what made their cars more than a car.The result;
a joyous and honest celebration of life in a Volkswagen.

copy.value: Here's a handful of the new DDBers whose impact we're already feeling, across IT, Engineering, Creative, Production, and Business Management.

Celebrating our humanity in all its diversity lies at the heart of DDB's creative culture.

<br class="all">
<br class="all">

It goes back to Bill Bernbach’s policy of hiring ‘nice and talented’ people.

<br class="all">
<br class="all">

It defines the way we behave and the way we treat each other. And in a very old human tradition we have a list of 10 behaviours to remind us – after all, to err is human.
We don’t pretend to be perfect. We don’t know it all, we strive to learn more.
We see each other’s strengths rather than pick at weaknesses.
We talk each other up, never down.
We don’t blame, or take all the credit – we share responsibility for the highs and lows.
We try to be honest  and authentic.
We speak as human beings – no jargon, no bullshit.

Macca’s fries are as iconic as the red and yellow packaging they come in.
But even the most loved icons must continue to reinvent themselves to remain relevant.
Based on the insight that Aussies like to do things their own way and aren’t afraid to bend the rules, Macca’s personified their fries, showing them to be full of new life and flavour.

subline.value: After a successful launch we had to generate a second burst of conversation, so we created a pop-up ‘Fries Only’ restaurant to celebrate the Macca’s icon and experiment with a few potential new flavours.

copy.value: The unanimous fan favourite was Sweet Chilli and Sour Cream. This became the focus of our summer campaign.

subline.value: The Loaded Fries platform illustrates its ability to remain on the menu long term. Now let’s let the fries do the talking…

meta-title.value: McDonald’s CYT Father Daughter | DDB Sydney

copy.value: How do you prove to mums and dads that they can love Maccas too?
Parents are always putting their children first, which can often lead to compromising on what satisfies their own tastes and comfort, to keep the kids happy.
That’s why up until Create Your Taste came along, a trip to Macca’s was usually just for those those little rascals in the back seat.
But in this Create Your Taste campaign, we celebrated the fact that (just for a moment), parents can now enjoy a little grown-up pleasure when they take the family for a meal at Macca’s…
… and amplified the notion that parents will do anything for love.
Gourmet Burgers have changed the way people think about Maccas…etc etc. We achieved XX sales, etc ect.

DDB is currently looking for a range of creatives to join DDB on the back of some significant and exciting business growth.

We are looking for creatives who have a passion for breakthrough creative ideas, contemporary thinking and execution plus a desire to learn and grow.<br class="all"><br class="all">

If you are interested in exploring these opportunities please send your folio to our Talent Directorb Sarah Crabbe  sarah.crabbe@syd.ddb.com<br class="all"><br class="all"><br class="all">
Aussie blokes were judging the Amarok by its cover, so we removed it.

The Amarok’s sleek European styling led people to believe
that it was too precious to handle tough Australian conditions

subline.value:
We Stripped the Amarok of everything that identified it,
forcing critics to judge it on performance alone.

We asked some of the Amarok’s greatest sceptics to guess
what it was, while the public guessed along with them.

We then revealed that the tough Naked Ute was actually the
Volkswagen Amarok challenging their prejudices, perceptions
and outdated opinions on how the Amarok really performs.

A total reach of 7.7 million with 125,000 unique
visitors to our unbranded website, more than 24,000
guesses an an immediate uplift in sales.

copy1.value: If you would like to know more about how we can help you to acheive Unreasonable growth plase contact Nic Taylor.

Hiring the best talent is literally one of the most important things we do at DDB. If you're nice and talented then we'd like to hear from you.
